questions.prompt: Who were the first people to arrive in Britain in what we call the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: The first people to live in Britain were hunter-gatherers, in what we call the Stone Age.

questions.prompt: When did Britain become permanently separated from the continent by the Channel?

questions.prompt: The Commonwealth has no power over its members and it cannot suspend their membership:

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements regarding the Black Death is NOT true?
options: One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales
It was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain
It affected children and old people only
Following the Black Death, there were labour shortages
questions.explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales. This was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain. Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages.

questions.explanation: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland also have parliaments or assemblies of their own, with devolved powers in defined areas.

questions.prompt: Which of the following lines from Shakespeare’s plays and poems is often still quoted?
questions.explanation: ‘All the world’s a stage’ is a line from William Shakespeare’s play As You Like It.

questions.prompt: How many volunteers did the National Trust have when it first was formed in 1895?
questions.explanation: The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers.

questions.prompt: In the UK, brutality and violence in the home is not a crime:
questions.explanation: In the UK, brutality and violence in the home is a serious crime.

questions.prompt: When did modern tennis evolve in England?
questions.explanation: Modern tennis evolved in England in the late 19th century.

questions.prompt: UK laws ensure that people are not treated unfairly in any area of life or work because of their age, disability, sex, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sexuality or marital status:
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: The population is very equally distributed over the four parts of the UK:
questions.explanation: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8%, and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

questions.prompt: Where was Anne Boleyn executed?
options: At the Houses of the Parliament
questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn was executed at the tower of London.

questions.prompt: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was not an independent country:
questions.explanation: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was an independent country.

questions.prompt: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them:
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: Where did Mary Stuart, the Queen of Scotland, spend most of her childhood?
questions.explanation: Mary Stuart, the Queen of Scotland, spent most of her childhood in France.

questions.prompt: During the Middle Ages, several cathedrals had windows of stained glass, telling stories about:
options: The journey of pilgrims to Canterbury
questions.explanation: During the middle ages, several cathedrals had windows of stained glass, telling stories about the Bible and Christian saints. The glass in York Minster is a famous example.

questions.prompt: Where does the UK Parliament sit?
questions.explanation: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster.

questions.prompt: When did King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan by which Wales annexed to the Crown of England?
questions.explanation: In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

questions.prompt: Which of the following public services can be controlled by the devolved administrations?
questions.explanation: Some public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

questions.prompt: The Welsh Assembly has been suspended on a few occasions:
questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly has been suspended on a few occasions.

questions.prompt: The settlements of Scottish and English Protestants in Ulster (the northern province of Ireland) during the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, who took over the land from Catholic landholders is known as:
questions.explanation: These settlements were known as plantations.

questions.prompt: Which of the following jobs is usually unpaid in England, Wales and Scotland?
options: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Scotland, Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of the local community and they usually work unpaid and do not need legal qualifications.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a traditional character of the pantomimes?
questions.explanation: One of the traditional characters of the pantomimes is the Dame, a woman played by a man.

questions.prompt: In the UK, most people live in towns and cities and very small parts of Britain are countryside:
questions.explanation: Most people live in towns and cities but much of Britain is still countryside.

questions.prompt: What was the symbol of Lancaster during the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: During the Wars of the Roses, the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose.

questions.prompt: After King Alfred the Great defeated the Vikings, many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain, especially in the east and north of England in an area called:
questions.explanation: Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain – especially in the east and north of England in an area known as the Danelaw.

questions.prompt: The Reform Act of 1832 increased the number of people with the right to vote:
questions.explanation: The Reform Act of 1832 had greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a famous example of stained glass?
questions.explanation: York Minster is a famous example of stained glass used on the windows of some cathedrals during the middle ages.

questions.prompt: Who is the head of the Church of England?
questions.explanation: The monarch is the head of the Church of England.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries?
questions.explanation: The Foreign Secretary is responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries.

questions.prompt: Which TWO of the following poems are from the Middle Ages?
options: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
questions.explanation: Poems which survive from the Middle Ages include Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales and a poem called Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, about one of the knights at the court of King Arthur.

questions.prompt: If a husband forces his wife to have sex, he can be charged with rape:
questions.explanation: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman’s husband, can be charged with rape.

questions.prompt: Who defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314?
questions.explanation: In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn.

questions.prompt: In the UK, owners are responsible for keeping their dog under control and for cleaning up after the animal in public places:
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: How long did the Hundred Years War fought between England and France last for?
questions.explanation: English kings fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).

questions.prompt: When did Gordon Brown take over as Prime Minister from his predecessor Tony Blair?
questions.explanation: Gordon Brown took over as Prime Minister from Tony Blair in 2007.

questions.prompt: The Life in the UK test is usually taken is English, although special arrangements can be made if you wish to take it in French.
questions.explanation: The Life in the UK test is usually taken is English, although special arrangements can be made if you wish to take it in Welsh or Scottish Gaelic.

questions.prompt: Where in England was one of the Anglo-Saxon kings buried with treasure and armour?
questions.explanation: The burial place of one of the Anglo-Saxon kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk.

questions.prompt: Which British writer wrote satirical novels including Brideshead Revisited?
questions.explanation: Evelyn Waugh wrote satirical novels, including Decline and Fall and Scoop. He is perhaps best known for Brideshead Revisited.

questions.prompt: Where is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe located?
options: Edinburgh, the capital of the Scotland
Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland
questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe.

questions.prompt: Which of the following sports began in the UK?
questions.explanation: Many famous sports, including cricket, football, lawn tennis, golf and rugby, began in Britain.

questions.prompt: Which famous architect designed Dumfries House?
questions.explanation: The Scottish architect Robert Adam designed the inside decoration as well as the building itself in great houses such as Dumfries House in Scotland.

questions.prompt: What did the Education Act of 1944 introduce?
options: Free primary education in England and Wales
Free secondary education in England and Wales
Free high school education in England and Wales
Free university education in England and Wales
questions.explanation: The Education Act 1944 (often called ‘The Butler Act’), introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.

questions.prompt: Which of the following tribes invaded Britain?
questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

questions.prompt: Many schools organise events such as book sales, toy sales or bringing food to sell to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities.
questions.explanation: This statement is TRUE.

questions.prompt: Do you need a TV licence for watching TV on a mobile phone?
questions.explanation: Everyone in the UK with a TV, computer or other medium which can be used for watching TV must have a television licence.

questions.prompt: What do you need to apply to become a British citizen?
options: Have lived in the UK for 3 years
Have a good understanding of life in the UK
questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have a good understanding of life in the UK.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a British overseas territory located in the South Atlantic?
questions.explanation: The Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory is located in the South Atlantic.

questions.prompt: Who wrote the novel Charlie and the Chocolate Factory?
questions.explanation: Roald Dahl is the author of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

questions.prompt: The Normans used a system of land ownership known as __________.
questions.explanation: The Normans used a system of land ownership known as feudalism.

questions.prompt: Who were the Huguenots?
questions.explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion. Many were educated and skilled and worked as scientists, in banking, or in weaving or other crafts.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Southern Ireland.
The official name of the country is Great Britain and Southern Ireland.
The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
The official name of the country is the United Kingdom and Great Ireland.
questions.explanation: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

questions.prompt: When was slavery abolished throughout the British Empire?
questions.explanation: In 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.prompt: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of the _________.
questions.explanation: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of the local community.

questions.prompt: Where can you find details about the small claims procedure?
options: At your local County Court or Sheriff Court
questions.explanation: You can get details about the small claims procedure from your local County Court or Sheriff Court.

questions.prompt: When is Mothering Sunday?
options: Is the Sunday three weeks before Easter.
Is the Sunday three weeks after Easter.
Is the Sunday three weeks before Christmas.
Is the Sunday three weeks after Christmas.
questions.explanation: Mothering Sunday (or Mother’s day) is the Sunday three weeks before Easter. Children send cards or buy gifts for their mothers.

questions.prompt: What should you do if your vehicle is over three years old?
options: Take it to the MOT every year.
Take it to the MOT 2 years.
Take it to the MOT 3 years.
Take it to the MOT six months.
questions.explanation: If you vehicle is over three years old, you must take it to the Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year.

questions.prompt: Which countries fought alongside Britain against Russia during the Crimean War?
questions.explanation: From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War.

questions.prompt: On average, boys leave school with better qualifications than girls.
questions.explanation: On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys.

questions.prompt: When did William of Orange invade England to proclaim himself king?
questions.explanation: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William of Orange to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland.

questions.prompt: Which British painter is considered to be the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting?
questions.explanation: Joseph Turner (1775-1851) was an influential landscape painter in a modern style. He is considered the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting.

questions.prompt: The development of the Bessemer process during the Industrial Revolution led to the development of which two industries:
questions.explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.

questions.prompt: What is the length of the Bayeux tapestry?
questions.explanation: The Bayeux Tapestry is nearly 70 metres (230 feet) long and is embroidered with coloured wool.

questions.prompt: Which of the following countries is not a member of the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: Costa Rica is not a member of the Commonwealth.

questions.prompt: In which of the following years did England win the World Cup?
questions.explanation: England won the World Cup in 1966 when it was captained by Bobby Moore.

questions.prompt: During the Battle of Trafalgar Britain fought against:
questions.explanation: Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

questions.prompt: What is the name given to the first formal anti-slavery groups set up in the late 1700s?
questions.explanation: The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.

questions.prompt: More women than men study at university.
questions.explanation: This statement is TRUE.

questions.prompt: Why did Ireland suffer a famine in the middle of the 19th century?
questions.explanation: In the middle of the century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation.

questions.prompt: What sort of battle was ‘the Battle of Britain’?
options: A naval battle against the Spanish.
An aerial battle against the French.
An aerial battle against the Germans.
A naval battle against the French.
questions.explanation: Hitler wanted to invade Britain, but before sending in troops, Germany needed to control the air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’, in the summer of 1940.

questions.prompt: Who is in charge of appointing the local Chief Constable?
questions.explanation: PCCs (Police and Crime Commissioners) set local police priorities and the local policing budget. They also appoint the local Chief Constable.

questions.prompt: What does the money from the National Insurance Contributions pay for (CHOOSE TWO)?
questions.explanation: The money raised from National Insurance Contributions is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

questions.prompt: How many British died on the first day alone of the Battle of Somme?
questions.explanation: The British attack of the Somme in July 1916, resulted in about 60,000 British casualties on the first day alone.

questions.prompt: When was the first Union flag created?
questions.explanation: The first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England.

questions.prompt: Which of the following territories is not part of the UK?
questions.explanation: The UK comprises England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. There are several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental principle of British life?
questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: democracy, the rule of law, individual liberty, tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs and participation in community life.

questions.prompt: What do Sir Terence Conran, Clarice Cliff and Thomas Chippendale have in common?
questions.explanation: Britain has produced many great designers, from Thomas Chippendale (who designed furniture in the 18th century) to Clarice Cliff (who designed Art Deco ceramics) to Sir Terence Conran (a 20th-century interior designer).

questions.prompt: Which of the following cities is not in Wales?
questions.explanation: Bradford is located in England.

questions.prompt: People on the electoral register with ages between 18 and 70 can be asked to serve on a jury.
questions.explanation: As well as getting the right to vote, people on the electoral register are randomly selected to serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do this.

questions.prompt: Which Saxon king of England was killed at the Battle of Hastings in 1066?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle.

questions.prompt: During the ‘swinging sixties’ Britain experienced a growth in:
options: Sports such as rowing and cycling
questions.explanation: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as the ‘swinging sixties’. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music.

questions.prompt: As a permanent resident or citizen of the UK you should:
options: Look after yourself and your family
Look after the area in which you live and the environment
questions.explanation: If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law, respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions, treat others with fairness, look after yourself and your family and look after the area in which you live and the environment.

questions.prompt: When did the BBC start the world’s first regular television service?
questions.explanation: The BBC started radio broadcasts in 1922 and began the world’s first regular television service in 1936.

questions.prompt: Women in Britain today make up about one third of the workforce.
questions.explanation: Women in Britain today make up about half of the workforce.

questions.prompt: The evacuation of British and French soldiers from France in a huge naval operation during WWII gave rise to which phrase:
questions.explanation: During WWII as France fell, the British decided to evacuate British and French soldiers from France in a huge naval operation. Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase ‘the Dunkirk spirit’.

questions.prompt: Which programme helps 16 and 17 year-olds develop their skills and are part in community projects?
questions.explanation: The National Citizen Service programme gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

questions.prompt: Queen Victoria became queen in:
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18.

questions.prompt: Who wrote the books ‘Pride and Prejudice’ and ‘Sense and Sensibility’?
questions.explanation: Jane Austen (1775-1817) was an English novelist. Her books include Pride and Prejudice and Sense and Sensibility.

questions.prompt: Which political party did Margaret Thatcher belong to?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

questions.prompt: In which city is the Principality Stadium located?
questions.explanation: The Principality Stadium is located in Cardiff.

questions.prompt: Who lost a lot of power and influence after the Battle of Culloden in 1746?
questions.explanation: The clans lost a lot of their power and influence after Culloden. Chieftains became landlords if they had the favour of the English king, and clansmen became tenants who had to pay for the land they used.

questions.prompt: What UK landmark was voted as Britain’s favourite view in 2007?
options: The Crown Jewels at the Tower of London
questions.explanation: In 2007, television viewers voted Wastwater as Britain’s favourite view.

questions.prompt: When did the development of a free press take place?
questions.explanation: From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence. Increasing numbers of newspapers began to be published.

questions.prompt: Which was the last successful foreign invasion of England?
questions.explanation: The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.

questions.prompt: Who was Richard Austen Butler?
questions.explanation: Richard Austen Butler (later Lord Butler) became a Conservative MP in 1923 and held several positions before becoming responsible for education in 1941.

questions.prompt: What kind of sport is played at the Wimbledon Championships?
questions.explanation: The most famous tennis tournament hosted in Britain is The Wimbledon Championships, which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club.

questions.prompt: Where was Isaac Newton from?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton was born in Lincolnshire, eastern England.

questions.prompt: Under which Act was The Kingdom of Great Britain created?
questions.explanation: The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was therefore agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.

questions.prompt: The Council of Europe has the power to make new laws.
questions.explanation: False. The Council of Europe has NO power to make laws but draws up conventions and charters, the most well-known of which is the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, usually called the European Convention on Human Rights.

questions.prompt: Which TWO British poets wrote about their experiences in the WWI?
options: John Keats and Alfred Lord Tennyson
questions.explanation: Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon were inspired to write about their experiences in the First World War.

questions.prompt: If you are found driving while exceeding the alcohol limit you will:
options: Not be allowed to drive again
Be taken home by the police
questions.explanation: If you are found driving while exceeding the alcohol limit you will be arrested.

questions.prompt: Which TWO of the following are core values of a civil servant?
questions.explanation: The core values of civil servants include: integrity, honesty, objectivity and impartiality (including being politically neutral).

questions.prompt: Which of the following countries belongs to the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: Nauru is a member of the Commonwealth.

questions.prompt: What is the name of the first Danish king to rule in England?
questions.explanation: Anglo-Saxon kings continued to rule what is now England, except for a short period when there were Danish kings. The first of these was Cnut, also named Canute.

questions.prompt: What name was given to the members of the Women’s Social and Political Union founded in 1903?
questions.explanation: In 1903 Emmeline Pankhurst helped found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU). This was the first group whose members were called ‘suffragettes’.

questions.prompt: It is a civil offence to owe money to someone and you might be taken to court.
questions.explanation: Owing money to someone is a civil offence.

questions.prompt: In which country of the British Empire did the Boer War take place?
questions.explanation: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent. The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers.

questions.prompt: Robert Louis Stevenson, Graham Greene and Sir Kingsley Amis were British writers.
questions.explanation: This statement is True.

questions.prompt: Which new industries developed in the UK during the Great Depression (choose 2 answers)?
questions.explanation: In 1929, the world entered the ‘Great Depression’ and some parts of the UK suffered mass unemployment. The effects of the depression of the 1930s were felt differently in different parts of the UK. The traditional heavy industries such as shipbuilding were badly affected but new industries – including the automobile and aviation industries – developed.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a traditional pub game?
questions.explanation: Pool and darts are traditional pub games.

questions.prompt: When was the Battle of Agincourt fought?
questions.explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V’s vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

questions.prompt: What is the Bessemer process?
options: An industrial process for the mass-production of iron
An industrial process for the mass-production of copper
An industrial process for the mass-production of titanium
An industrial process for the mass-production of steel
questions.explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.

questions.prompt: When did people learn to make bronze?
questions.explanation: Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze. We call this period the Bronze Age.

questions.prompt: When is the Jewish celebration known as Hanukkah normally celebrated?
questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days.

questions.prompt: What musical award is given during the Mercury Music Prize?
options: Best album from the UK and Ireland
Best solo artist from the UK
Best solo artist the UK and Ireland
questions.explanation: The Mercury Music Prize is awarded each September for the best album from the UK and Ireland.

questions.prompt: Who was Boudicca?
options: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans
One of the architects who built Hadrian’s Wall
One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Vikings
questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

questions.prompt: Which TWO of the following water sports are popular in the UK?
questions.explanation: Sailing continues to be popular in the UK, reflecting its maritime heritage. Rowing is also popular, both as a leisure activity and as a competitive sport.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Forcing another person to marry is a civil offence
Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence
Forcing another person to marry is not punished in the UK
Forcing another person to marry is common in the UK
questions.explanation: Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence.

questions.prompt: In the UK, what should dogs wear in public places?
options: A collar with the name and address of the owner
A collar with the name of the dog
A tracking device in case they get lost
Clothes to avoid the cold in the winter
questions.explanation: All dogs in public places must wear a collar showing the name and address of the owner.

questions.prompt: Where do UK residents need to register their car or motorcycle?
options: At the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)
questions.explanation: If you are resident in the UK, your car or motor cycle must be registered at the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

questions.prompt: Popular social networking websites in the UK include:
questions.explanation: Social networking websites such as Facebook and Twitter are a popular in the UK.

questions.prompt: According to the 2011 Census, what percentage of the population identified themselves as Muslim?
questions.explanation: In the 2011 Census, 59% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (4.8%), Hindu (1.5%), Sikh (0.8%), Jewish or Buddhist (both less than 0.5%).

questions.prompt: How often are elections held for the National Assembly for Wales?
questions.explanation: The National Assembly for Wales has 60 Assembly members (AMs) and elections are held every four years using a form of proportional representation.

questions.prompt: Who was the British Minister after Margaret Thatcher?
questions.explanation: John Major was Prime Minister after Mrs Thatcher, and helped establish the Northern Ireland peace process.

questions.prompt: What name is given to the person appointed by local authorities to be the ceremonial leader of a particular council?
questions.explanation: Many local authorities appoint a mayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council. In some towns, a mayor is elected to be the effective leader of the administration.

questions.prompt: What is the meaning of the term ‘first past the post’?
options: In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected
If no political party wins a majority, two parties may join and govern together
If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election
The Speaker will be chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot
questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called ‘first past the post’. In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected.

questions.prompt: Who defeated Emperor Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815?
questions.explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.prompt: Which court deals with the MOST serious cases in Scotland, such as murder?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, serious cases are heard in a Sheriff Court with either a sheriff or a sheriff with a jury. The most serious cases in Scotland, such as murder, are heard at a High Court with a judge and jury.

questions.prompt: What was the symbol of the House of Tudor?
options: A red rose with a white rose inside it
A white rose with a red rose inside it
questions.explanation: The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

questions.prompt: What animal is represented in the Welsh flag?
questions.explanation: There is also an official Welsh flag, which shows a Welsh dragon. The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already untied with England.

questions.prompt: Which famous economist developed ideas about economics during the 18th century and which are still referred to today?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’. Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today.

questions.prompt: Who is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth?
options: The President of the United States
The Prime Minister of the UK
questions.explanation: The King is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth.

questions.prompt: What time do pubs usually open during the week?
questions.explanation: Pubs are usually open during the day from 11.00 am (12 noon on Sundays).

questions.prompt: In which TWO movie categories does Britain continue to be particularly strong at?
questions.explanation: Britain continues to be particularly strong in special effects and animation movies.

questions.prompt: Which British artist was a portrait painter who often painted people in country or garden scenarios?
questions.explanation: Thomas Gainsborough (1727-88) was a portrait painter who often painted people in country or garden scenery.

questions.prompt: During which religious celebration do Muslims sacrifice an animal to eat?
questions.explanation: Many Muslims sacrifice an animal to eat during Eid ul Adha.

questions.prompt: Which country invented rugby?
questions.explanation: Rugby originated in England in the early 19th century and is very popular in the UK today.

questions.prompt: Who were the Huguenots?
questions.explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

questions.prompt: Which British scientist showed that gravity applied to the whole universe?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica (‘Mathematical Principle of Natural Philosophy’), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe.

questions.prompt: Which composer wrote music for King George I and for his son, George II?
questions.explanation: George Frederick Handel wrote the Water Music for King George I and Music for the Royal Fireworks for his son, George II.

questions.prompt: When did the English civil war start?
questions.explanation: Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country spilt into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

questions.prompt: During the 19th century, the UK was the world’s major producer of which THREE materials?
questions.explanation: British industry led the world in the 19th century. The UK produced more that half of the world’s iron, coal and cotton cloth.

questions.prompt: Which TWO of the following British athletes have won gold medals in the Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: Dame Kelly Holmes and Jessica Enis won gold medals in the Olympic Games.

questions.prompt: The Romans remained in Britain for 500 years.

questions.prompt: Which country invaded the Falkland Islands in 1982?
